properties.grant_description: "Black Diamonds" is a documentary that highlights coal extraction exploits throughout Appalachia. This grant is part of FPW's ongoing outreach/education aspect of the Abandoned Mine Lands Fund reauthorization. Grant funds will support the dissemination of 20 DVDs of the film to strategic partners throughout the region.

The Penn State College of Agricultural Sciences joins forces with the PA Department of Agriculture and the Penn Sate Institute of Energy and Environment to convene a statewide working conference, Agriculture and Environment: Achieving Balance. The conference is designed to identify new solutions to the old, yet challenging issue of nutrients in the environment. This event is scheduled for June 2 and 3 in Harrisburg.

The Rose Valley/Mill Creek Watershed Association is seeking funding to conduct an annual watershed festival/fishing derby on the Rose Valley Lake. The event includes activities such as watershed awareness, lake habitat and aquatic species education, PA Fish and Boat Commission educational programs, litter cleanup contest, and a cane pole fishing derby.

The Six Mile Run Area Watershed Committee seeks funding to support their 5th Annual Watershed Festival. The Festival will bring together environmental groups and agencies, along with the pubic, to celebrate the watershed improvements made thus far and raise awareness of the problems that remain.
seller_address: 187 Municpal Rd. PO Box 57, Defiance, PA, 16633

properties.grant_description: The intent of the “Building Collaboration for Effective Watershed Stewardship” project is to coordinate 14 established watershed associations in Allegheny County to engage residents and visitors in a better understanding of their responsibility to care for our regional water resources.

Trout Unlimited seeks support for the West Branch Susquehanna Restoration Symposium. The purpose of the symposium is to promote and continue the momentum of the West Branch Susquehanna Restoration Initiative, which is aimed at the cleanup of abandoned mine drainage throughout the region.
properties.grant_name: West Branch Susquehanna Restoration Symposium IV

properties.grant_description: The Washington County Watershed Alliance (WCWA), the Washington County Conservation District, and the Cross Creek Watershed Association have been continually working to restore a portion of stream bank along Cross Creek at the site of Meadowcroft Rockshelter. The goals of the project are: 1) to restore 300 feet of Cross Creek by installing a cross rock vane to direct the flow of water away from the banks and toward the center stream channel and 2) to reintroduce historically native plan species in a riparian area between the stream channel and the parking area.
The Western PA Coalition for Abandoned Mine Reclamation is seeking funding for its co-sponsorship of the 10th Annual Abandoned Mine Reclamation Conference.

The Western PA Conservancy seeks funding support for the 7th Annual Westmoreland Earth Day. The mission of the event is to demonstrate the connections that exist between members of the community and local natural resources. Since the first Westmoreland Earth Day in 2002, nearly 12,000 people have attended this event.

The 7th Annual Earth Day at St. Vincent College is themed “Greening Your Footprint.” The organizers of the event seek funding to be used for tent rentals and to support an alternative fuel vehicle to transport attendees.

The Citizens Coal Council is a coalition designed to galvanize the coalfield justice movement and protect people, land, and water from the harm caused by coal extraction. The group seeks funding to continue their collaborative efforts.

French Creek is among the most ecologically significant and richest waterways in the northeastern United States. It contains more species of fish and freshwater mussels than any other stream in the northeastern United States, prompting one expert to maintain that “French Creek is undeniably one of Pennsylvania’s foremost aquatic treasures.” The Nature Conservancy named French Creek one of its original “Last Great Places,” and considers French Creek one of the thirty most important bodies of freshwater in the United States, Latin America, and the Caribbean. In results from a recent study, French Creek consistently rises to the top of a group of regional watersheds when viewed from perspectives such as water quality and biodiversity.

The Buffalo Creek Watershed Alliance (BCWA) seeks funding for the restoration of Buffalo Creek. This project will include characterization of water quality and flow in the headwaters to determine the level of impacts and required remediation to restore water quality. The plan will also address the evaluation of remediation approaches and the development of a conceptual treatment approach to add adequate alkalinity to the stream in order to mitigate the impacts of acidic deposition. BCWA hopes to move toward the construction of a passive treatment system.

The Agricultural Initiative is working on the watershed level to address Chesapeake Bay water quality through enhancing assistance to farmers to adopt conservation practices and advancing market-based approaches to managing animal waste while simultaneously strengthening the economic sustainability of farming communities in watersheds threatened by land development.

In order to provide leadership among youth and citizens in implementing the Clean Water Act, Environment America is seeking scholarship funding to support a summer internship for a Water Policy Specialist.

Recent increases in development within the PA Route 60 corridor have caused a change in both the amount and timing of flood events that flow through the Raredon Run watershed, a tributary to Raccoon Creek. Four sites within the Raredon Run watershed have been identified for streambank stabilization and/or restoration. Each site has eroding streambanks near homes or roadways and excess deposition of sediment within the streambed that has changed the dimension, pattern, and stream profile. The problems associated with each site are largely caused by a lack of riparian buffers.

The purpose of this distribution is for continued support of the Coldwater Heritage Partnerships program. This year's awards will support the development of Coldwater Conservation Plans for Beaver Creek (Schuykill County), Miller Run (Huntingdon County), North Fork of Powell's Creek (Dauphin County), Paradise Creek (Monroe County), South Branch Little Aughwick (Fulton County), and Stony Run (Chester County).

The Kiski-Conemaugh Stream Team coordinates a volunteer based water monitoring program, provides technical assistance and environmental education, and implements several special projects. The goal of the Stream Team is to engage residents, particularly youth, in restoring, maintaining, and enjoying our natural resources.

The Lower Penns Creek Watershed Association with the Conservation Districts of Union and Snyder Counties have partnered with Susquehanna University and EcoAnalysts, Inc. to assess the main-stem of the Lower Penns Creek Watershed. This assessment will help focus the Association’s efforts by providing usable and up-to-date data that will be utilized to determine priority areas within the watershed and build membership and partnerships.

In October 2006, the Stewards of the Lower Susquehanna (SOLS) and the Lower Susquehanna Riverkeeper began the Conowingo Sediments Outreach and Education Project by bringing together expert scientists who had been studying the problem. Now SOLS must build public and legislative support for funding the research and solutions needed to mitigate the sediment accumulation problems. They plan to do this through public meetings throughout PA and MD, distributing educational handouts, creating websites and video and by continuing meetings with their state decision-makers and other conservation and community organizations.

The Mill Creek watershed is negatively impacted by nonpoint source agricultural pollution. Previously completed streambank fencing has had a positive impact as documented by the PA Fish and Boat Commission - parts of the river now support fish stocking efforts. This project reflects an opportunity to work with traditionally hesitant Amish and Mennonite groups. The overall project intends to continue educational efforts and to install an additional 20,000 linear feet of streambank fencing.

Program funds are needed to support the only ongoing grassroots, collaborative initiative to enhance the aesthetic, economic and health value of Pittsburgh’s rivers by cleaning man-made debris from riverbanks within the Pittsburgh pool. Every year flood waters strew tons of man-made debris along the banks of Pittsburgh’s Rivers. This debris decreases the aesthetic quality and the economic value of the riverfront and forms breeding grounds for mosquitoes and other disease vectors. Goals of the upcoming season focus on completing the inventory that weather prohibited executing last year and working to engage new groups in the program, including recreational river users.

The PA Organization for Watersheds and Rivers (POWR) is seeking funding to pursue a merger with the PA Environmental Council (PEC). Much of the negotiations, including the decision to move forward with this merger, have already been completed. The remaining work involves: changing/formalizing IRS paperwork, consolidating staff, and developing operational budgets. Funding is also being sought to disseminate information regarding SMCRA.

Currently there is no Rivers Conservation Plan for Wills Creek, largely an unpopulated watershed with pristine locations and rugged terrain. Through a joint partnership with Maryland Department of Environment, Somerset Conservation District will work with Maryland officials to modify their stream assessment tool and apply it to the watershed’s headwaters. The preassessment data is intended to lay the framework for a 2010 Rivers Conservation Plan grant submission, and serve as an update to the County's Wills Creek Implementation Strategy.

The Stroud Research Center is seeking funding to assess impacts of acid mine drainage and its remediation on ecosystem structure and function of streams draining to the Chesapeake Bay. The goal of this project is to determine the extent to which AMD impairs streams in order to understand nutrient losses to downstream reaches and the Chesapeake Bay.

The Susquehanna Greenway Partnership is seeking funding to develop and implement land conservation strategies and environmentally sensitive design practices to protect and enhance the natural areas and water resources of the Susquehanna Greenway corridor. The goals of this project are: establish land conservation priorities and partnerships, advocate and promote conservation and environmentally sensitive design, and protect regional priority lands.

WVIA TV seeks funding to help support the development of a DVD entitled “Nutrient Trading: Reducing Pollutants in Our Waters,” which examines the nutrient impacts to PA’s waterways, and highlights efforts, programs, and tools being used to improve water quality. The production will be an outreach and education tolls that will be used for advancing the Nutrient Trading Program.

Capital Resource Conservation and Development Council, Inc. seeks funding to provide administration and project planning/implementation costs for two regional projects. The funds will cover the costs of bringing together and working with the project partners to plan and implement important conservation in the Mill Creek watershed. Additionally, funds will support the application of amended poultry manure for mine land reclamation and biomass production.

Confer Construction seeks funding for a Field Day presentation on requirements for Act 537 implementation for on-lot septic systems in rural communities. Attendees will include staff from the Huntingdon County Conservation District, local township supervisors, and the general public. The goals of the workshop are consistent with the reduction of nitrogen and phosphorus required under the Chesapeake Bay agreement.
Funds were used to pay for preparation for the Huntingdon County Planning Commission and Geisinger Health Care dinner at Huntingdon Farm.
The Keystone Conservation Trust seeks funding to help nonprofit organizations reach qualified donors and explain that they can sell real estate and donate money to conservation at the same time.
seller_address: 336 King of Prussia Rd., Radnor, PA, 19087

properties.grant_description: The League of Women Voters seeks funding to conduct Phase I of a Strategic Program Evaluation for the Water Resources Education Network Project, a program of the League of Women Voters Pennsylvania Citizen Education Fund.

The Stewards of the Lower Susquehanna wish to convene a meeting of chief scientists, economists, and manufacturers that have agreed to review the current information and options available for addressing the Lower Susquehanna River dam sediments and the threats from these sediments to the Chesapeake Bay.

The Mountain Watershed Association seeks funding to continue its work opposing the redesignation of Grinnage Run. The Foundation Coal petition to downgrade four streams within the South Fork of Ten Mile Creek is the second industry-generated petition submitted to the Environmental Quality Board to reclassify streams in southwestern PA.

The Ohio River Basin Consortium seeks funding for its Research and Education Symposium. This event will be hosed by Carnegie Mellon University and will focus on the topic of Urban Water and Watersheds in the Ohio River Basin.

The Pennsylvania Grazing Lands Conservation Initiative (GLCI) is hosting the National GLCI Steering Committee for the annual fall meeting and tour of some of Pennsylvania’s premier grazing operations. In order to achieve a high quality tour and program, GLCI is looking for financial sponsors for this event.
properties.grant_name: GLCI Steering Committee Meeting and Tour

properties.grant_description: The PA Council of Trout Unlimited seeks funding to help with administrative support for the Coldwater Heritage program.

The Roaring Run Watershed Association seeks funding to help generate river data required for their ongoing Energy Harvest Grant Program. The program’s goal is to develop and test a microhydroturbine power generation system that will power an on-site AMD treatment system.

Stream Restoration, Inc. is seeking funding for their 7th Annual Ohio River Watershed Celebration. Due to the overwhelming response, this year’s event has been expanded to include a second boat. The theme for this year’s event is “Innovative Energy for a Green World” and will highlight many points of interest along the Ohio River.

The Western Pennsylvania Conservancy seeks funding to provide support for convening a group of twenty conservation and environmental organizations across the state to plan for a significant funding campaign. Based on initial meetings, the new funding campaign will provide financial resources to programs now being funded under the Growing Greener program aimed at conserving our natural resources, restoring damaged resources, and creating prosperous communities.

The Westmoreland Conservation District (WCD) seeks funding for conducting on-site wastewater education to the residents of Westmoreland and adjacent counties. This funding will help enable WCD to develop hands-on educational tools and information for the promotion of responsible on-site septic system care and maintenance.

The Alliance for Aquatic Resource Monitoring has limited staff and availability to work with watershed groups and currently only assist about 7 groups a year. Their services revolve around water quality monitoring. With a limited availability to reach and assist groups, ALLARM has determined that a web-based mentor program could assist in reaching more groups. The system will include an online toolbox that will provide groups tutorials that will assist with monitoring protocols, sampling design criteria, and data interpretation.

The Upper West Branch Susquehanna River Conservation Plan identified the restoration of Anderson Creek watershed as a priority in its management recommendations. The newly completed Total Maximum Daily Load (TMDL) study for Anderson Creek has also identified the watershed as severely impacted and provides specific loading reductions for: iron, manganese, aluminum, and acidity concentrations. This project will support the preliminary survey and AMD treatment system for the Smouse Strip, the first source of AMD degradation to an unnamed tributary to Little Anderson Creek.

The Strip Mining Handbook provides citizens an understanding of their rights to monitor and participate in the enforcement of environmental laws. The book provides critical information to landowners dealing with the pressures of and degradation caused by mining.

The Beech Creek Watershed Association (BCWA), in cooperation with state and local agencies, has undertaken a comprehensive watershed restoration project for the Beech Creek watershed, an area highly degraded by abandoned mine drainage. The specific scope of work associated with this project includes: data collection, engineering design, and permitting. The goal of the project is to develop and permit a site plan for construction in a future phase. This will be the first of four phases of the project.

Strong Communities, Healthy Waters: Empowering Farm Communities in the Chesapeake Region is an agricultural initiative working at the watershed level to address Chesapeake Bay water quality. The initiative enhances assistance to farmers who adopt conservation practices. This effort will also advance market-based approaches to managing animal waste and strengthen the economic sustainability of farming communities in threatened watersheds.

Muddy Creek Trout Unlimited is developing a Rivers Conservation Plan for the Muddy Creek watershed. The goal of the project is to collect additional data on wetlands and streams within the watershed in order to identify and prioritize stream reaches and wetlands that should be restored or preserved.

The water quality of Emigh Run is severely impacted by abandoned mine drainage. In order to restore life in the 22 acre Morrisdale Dam, Emigh Run must be remediated as it is the dam’s only water source. The Emigh Run Morrisdale Watershed Association is proposing to design and install a passive treatment system that will abate an abandoned mine discharge named ER-35. Through the completion of a watershed assessment and development of a restoration plan, ER-35 was determined to be Priority Project #5 in the watershed.

The Energy Conservation Council of Pennsylvania board of directors, in support of the Stop the Towers’ effort to stop Allegheny Energy’s Tran Allegheny Interstate Line (TrAIL) and the opposition of NEIT corridor designation, has agreed to affiliate with Stop the Towers in order to promote energy conservation, community outreach/education and support fundraising efforts.
seller_address: 189 Hoge Summit Rd., Eighty Four, PA, 15330

properties.grant_description: Shoup's Run has seen a near miraculous recovery by treating nearly all of the AMD impacts within the watershed. In order to maintain the recovering watershed, the Shoup's Run Watershed Association (SRWA) proposes stockpiling the alkaline martial that is used to treat several of the acidic discharges in the watershed. By stockpiling limestone sand strategically throughout the watershed, SRWA will be able to quickly add the necessary alkalinity needed to prevent any damaging rises in acidity. Additionally, the project will incorporate alkaline addition at the Green Garden's project site.
properties.grant_name: Shoup's Run - Miller Run Alkalinity Addition

properties.grant_description: The purpose of this project is to reduce nutrient and sediment pollution to the Neshannock Creek watershed while providing recreational/educational opportunities to all members of the community with a special focus on disabled veterans and other physically challenged individuals. The completed project will include: an easily maintained sediment and nutrient trap, a 1.5 acre wetland and open water area, a paved nature observation trail, a handicapped preference fishing platform, picnic facilities, and a paved parking area.

Chapter 93 of the PA Code has identified Mill Run as a High Quality Coldwater fishery in the Indian Creek watershed. Mill Run has been suffering from stream bank erosion for many years. This erosion was beginning to widen the stream and diminish the riffle/run/pool habitat critical to a trout fishery. In addition, the riparian areas along the stream have been cut down and mowed over time, removing any root systems that would stabilize the bank and eradicating riparian buffers that cool the water. The silt loading has diminished the number of of aquatic insects and the lack of cover warmed water temperatures, threatening the cold-water species.
The North Area Environmental Council is seeking funding to develop a Rivers Conservation Plan for Pine Creek.

Stream Restoration Incorporated looks to develop a Rivers Conservation Plan for Slippery Rock Creek, a stream that is severely impacted by abandoned mine drainage. This is a two-year project that will server Beaver, Butler, Lawrence, Mercer, and Venango counties. SRI will also work with citizens and local/county planners to address other ecological concerns including urbanization of the I-79 corridor and its impact on prime agricultural lands.

"The Strip Mining Handbook" was published by the Environmental Policy Institute/Friends of the Earth in 1990 as a citizen’s guide for coalfield residents on the 1977 federal law regulating surface coal mining operations. The Handbook has assisted citizens all over the nation’s coalfields in exercising their rights under the federal Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act. With the 30th Anniversary of the federal law having passed last year, and with numerous judicial and regulatory decisions that have affected the law and citizen’s right, an update to the book is long overdue. The Natural Resources Law Center at the University of Colorado Law School is committed to preparing this update and has begun the redrafting of several chapters and is hoping to attract modest support for this effort. It is a vital educational tool that outlines particular provisions of the newly reauthorized Abandoned Mine Land Fund and its SMCRA provisions.

Upstream development has increased storm water flows in Dents Run. Streambank fencing has helped to address sandbar formation and excess sedimentation, but stormwater is still problematic. The goal of this project is to stabilize approximately 400 feet of eroding streambank to protect several streamside structures and install natural stream design devices to control high water flows, dissipate stream energy, and improve habitat.

Mill Creek is a significant tributary to the Allegheny River. Although it is a trout stocked fishery, much of the upper watershed is impaired by excessive nutrients. The stream crosses the Allegheny River Recreational Trail near its mouth. Camping, fishing, and unrestricted ATV use of the area near the mouth have resulted in severe streambank instability and excessive erosion increasing the sediment deposition into Mill Creek.

Cedar Run is an urban watershed that supports a naturally reproducing brown trout fishery. This project aims to alert homeowners and businesses on how their actions impact this fragile ecosystem. The Alliance seeks to facilitate the installation of at least three stormwater retrofit projects that will not only manage stormwater flow, but also provide demonstration sites that will help improve the general acceptance of natural stormwater control.

This project will relocate 220 linear feet of headwaters on Bear Loop Run. This stream segment courses through an abandoned strip mine cut, which severely degrades the water quality and negatively impacts fish populations. The project is also expected to reduce down-slope mine seeps.

The purpose of this project is to improve the Tangascootack Site #1 treatment system. The original design principles of the system did not adequately address treatment needs and allows acidic water to flow into the South Fork of the Tangascootack.

The Espy Run watershed is heavily impacted by abandoned mine drainage (AMD). Portions of the creek disappear into underground boreholes, leaving the channel dry. When water flow resurfaces further down the channel, it is heavily impacted by AMD and is devoid of aquatic life. The existing passive treatment system installed at the Espy Run seep was constructed in 1996 and does not treat the entire discharge. This project will improve water quality by treating the entire discharge.

Over the past five years, the Coldwater Heritage Partnership has funded 51 Coldwater Conservation Plans. The initial investment of approximately $250000 in Coldwater Conservation Grants has helped leverage well over $2000000 in additional projects. This year's awards will support the development of Coldwater Conservation Plans for Clark Creek (Dauphin County), Coplay Creek (Lehigh County), Headwaters of Fishing Creek (Columbia and Sullivan Counties), Hokendauqua Creek (Northampton County), Larry's Creek (Lycoming County), Little Paint Creek (Somerset County), and Willow Run (Juniata County).

The ultimate goal of the Emigh Run Lakeside Watershed Association is to restore Hubler Run to a trout fishery. The current Hubler 1 passive treatment system needs retrofitted to improve system performance during high-flow conditions. This rehabilitation project, combined with the Hubler 2 construction project and the Hubler Run 3 feasibility study will address three sources of abandoned mine drainage to Hubler Run.
These funds will be used to help defray the litigation costs for the Energy Conservation Council’s opposition to Allegheny Energy’s TrAIL Project.
seller_address: 189 Hoge Summit Rd., Eighty Four, PA, 15330

properties.grant_description: The Anthracite Coal Region has a multitude of detailed mine maps that are inventoried and in good shape. Despite the state’s efforts to develop a State Water Plan, mine pools are poorly understood and their overall value has not been assessed. With advancements in technology, the Eastern PA Coalition for Abandoned Mine Reclamation proposes to digitize existing mine maps, correlating geology, hydrology, and water chemistry to estimate the total water resource available in underground mine complexes.

When a dam was removed from Wolf Creek in 2005, the previously trapped sediment began making its way downstream. The transported sediment formed gravel bars and altered flow patterns. This project aims to remove excess sediment, stabilize eroded banks, and develop healthy riparian buffers.

Natural Biodiversity seeks funding to develop and demonstrate prioritized invasive plant and noxious weed management on riparian lands within the most precious and vulnerable areas in the Juniata watershed. This project will systematically identify priority prevention and rapid response areas, management strategies, and will demonstrate exemplary management regarding weed problems in riparian forest buffers.

On behalf of the Chesapeake Bay Watershed Coalition’s “Chose Clean Water” Campaign, the Nation Wildlife Federation seeks funding to support efforts to build a coalition comprised of non-governmental organizations to restore and protect the Chesapeake Bay through federal advocacy and accountability, and action at the state and local levels.

The Big Spring Run Floodplain Restoration Project will restore the floodplain along 3850 feet of the stream by removing legacy sediment that has accumulated over the past 150 years due to a downstream mill dam. Streambank erosion will be significantly reduced with this restoration, resulting in reduced nutrient and sediment loads delivered to the Conestoga River watershed.

The PA Land Trust Association (PALTA) seeks funding to support its national and state level efforts to prevent the construction of interstate transmission lines that would increase production and emissions from coal-fired power plants. Specifically, PALTA will monitor the electric industry, gather, analyze and disseminate relevant data to allies, and facilitate communications among those working to stop coal-fired transmission expansion.

The Schuylkill Headwaters Association (SHA) is seeking funds to hire two Office of Surface Mining VISTA members. The first position will focus his efforts on issues within the Schuylkill River Watershed. The second position will focus her efforts on assisting five other watershed groups covering the remainder of the county. One of the important functions of the VISTA positions is to complete inventories of acid mine drainage seeps by doing stream walks. This valuable function is the first step in watershed restoration and the access of funding from the Office of Surface Mining, administered through PA's Bureau of Abandoned Mine Reclamation office.

The primary goal of this project is to reduce the iron deposition from the Woodville discharge to Chartiers Creek. This will eliminate a highly visible iron scar and substantially decrease degradation of the Chartiers Creek backchannel and main stem. The discharge is easily accessible making it a prime location for high school and college tours that highlight AMD pollution. Once completed, interpretive signage will provide groups with a more complete educational experience.
The purpose of this distribution is for the statewide public opinion survey consultant fee.

To address critical watershed issues, the Westmoreland Conservation District (WCD) is proposing to create a family of new education materials for landowners regarding on-lot septic management, private water sources, and pond management. WCD intends to produce and begin distributing these materials in the next few months so that they are available to address the immediate needs in the county. WCD will also begin the process of updating their highly successful and well used bioinfiltration poster and undertake a strategic discussion with key members of the community to identify longer-term needs and fixes in these critical watershed areas.

The Blair County Conservation District seeks funding for the Cove Cover Crop Conference. This event is aimed at promoting cover cropping as a choice practice needed in the Cove area watershed. These funds will cover the costs of a pre-conference meeting that will connect conference speakers, partners, and organizers to members of the water authority, municipality officials, and other land/water community decision makers.

The Brownsville Area Revitalization Corps (BARC) seeks funding to develop a grant application to the DCNR Community Conservation Partnerships Program to match the cost to print water trail maps. The water trail project will serve as the catalyst to foster a permanent watershed group that will oversee the protection and restoration of the Middle Monongahela River.
seller_address: PO Box 97, 69 Market St., Brownsville, PA, 15417

properties.grant_description: The Capital Resource Conservation and Development Area Council seeks funding to provide administration and project planning/implementation costs to four short-term projects. These funds will be used to cover the costs of bringing together and working with the project partners to: 1) plan and implement viable solutions to land conservation strategies in the southwest portion of Cumberland, Franklin, Adams, and York counties; 2) demonstrate water harvesting strategies through technical assistance in the set-up and maintenance of rain barrels and other appropriate practices for homeowners in Cumberland/Franklin county watersheds; 3) provide technical guidance to landowners for planting/maintaining native riparian buffers; and 4) to support/demonstrate the connections between agricultural land preservation efforts and the marketing/growth of interest in local fresh food products in the regions.

During the 2008 Regional Conservancy Roundatable Event, the conservancies collaborated on solutions for needs within their own organizations that could assist them in their efforts. One of the the overarching items for all was a general need to inform and influence the general "marketing" of land protection as an integral part of local economic development and compatible growth in the region.  To that end, the Central Pennsylvania Conservancy seeks funding to hold a training workshop focused on "crafting and sending a common message" through website and networking tools.

The City of Johnstown seeks funding to determine the feasibility of using the abandoned mine drainage from the Inclined Plane site for pretreatment use in ground source heat exchange. Specifically, these funds will be used to: determine the sustainable mine flow capacity, assess existing infrastructure beneath the city, determine available BTUs for heating/cooling capacities, and developing costs for implementation.
These funds will support a teacher workshop on alternative energy issues to be held at Huntingdon Farm.

The Eastern PA Coalition for Abandoned Mine Reclamation seeks funding to offset the costs of a Request for Qualifications document preparation and development of a Technical Assistance Review Committee for the Shamokin Creek watershed and an AMD treatment feasibility study for industrial development.
The Forum for Pennsylvania’s Heartland seeks funding to help underwrite the cost of the Susquehanna River Heartland Coalition for Environmental Studies’ annual report, “Pulse of the Heartland 2009.”
These funds will cover the costs of the Foundation of Pennsylvania Watersheds membership dues to the Grantmakers of Western Pennsylvania.

The Juniata Clean Water Partnership seeks funding to support its 9th Annual Juniata River Sojourn, a five day event that incorporates resource awareness, watershed education, and appreciation for the beauty and wildlife in the Juniata watershed.

The Keystone Conservation Trust seeks funding to help non-profit organizations reach qualified donors and explain how they can sell their real estate and donate money to conservation at the same time.
seller_address: 336 King of Prussia Rd., Radnor, PA, 19087

properties.grant_description: The Kiski-Conemaugh Stream Team seeks funding to support the activities associated with Outdoor Heritage Month, including Outdoor Adventures.

The Lake Erie-Allegheny Earth Force seeks funding to support travel and venue costs associated with hosting its Youth Summits. This program is aimed at educating students in the preservation of water quality through non-point source pollution prevention, storm water management, water quality monitoring, riparian improvement, water conservation, keeping pharmaceuticals out of sewage, and reducing air pollution.

The Loyalhanna Watershed Association (LWA) seeks funding to support a “Where in the Watershed” tour, an education program designed to give citizens in the Loyalhanna watershed an opportunity to experience an up close look at several of the successful improvement projects carried out by LWA over the past few years.

The Loyalhanna Watershed Association (LWA) seeks funding to support the “Trout in the Classroom Discovery Program.” This program was designed by LWA and Forbes Trail Trout Unlimited to give students the opportunity to raise native brook trout in their classroom. Students will learn about and care for the young fish as they develop from eggs to fingerling trout before releasing them into an approved stream.

The Mid-Atlantic Exotic Pest Plant Council seeks funding to support the proceedings of the 2009 Mind-Atlantic Invasive Plant Conference entitled “Invasive Plants: Complicating Factors in Invasive Plant Management.”

The Mountain Watershed Association seeks funding to support the organization and convening of coalition-building efforts as home of the Youghiogheny Riverkeeper and on behalf of the Youghiogheny River. The River is threatened by excessive water withdrawals and proposed resource extraction.
The Mountain Watershed Association seeks funding to support its participation in the formation of an alliance of organizations working on various coal-related issues in southwestern Pennsylvania.
The Mountain Watershed Association seeks funding to support its participation in the Longwall Mining Conference to be held at Fontbonne University in St. Louis, Missouri.
These funds support the efforts of the National Wildlife Federation’s newly established Chesapeake Mid-Atlantic Regional Center.

Natural Biodiversity seeks funding to support the creation of an internship position for their Habitat Project. The intern will assist in performing planned habitat restoration, citizen engagement, and community education projects throughout the summer of 2009.
Natural Biodiversity seeks funding to support an internship position to assist with the organization's invasive species projects.

Natural Biodiversity seeks funding to develop a strategic plan for updating and identifying the key organizational and programmatic initiatives that will propel the effort toward future success and fulfillment of its mission.

The Pennsylvania Land Trust Association (PALTA) seeks funding to support the 2009 Pennsylvania Land Conservation Conference themed “Working Together to Protect Our Land, Water and Communities.” This event will provide attendees the opportunity to harness innovative tools and foster new relationships.

The Western Pennsylvania Environmental Awards Program recognizes and honors outstanding achievements of organizations, programs, and individuals in a wide range of environmental initiatives throughout the region. These funds will pay for two tickets to the Awards Dinner and ceremony. Linda McKenna Boxx, the president of the Allegheny Trail Alliance and the driving force behind the creation of the Great Allegheny Passage - a 150-mile trail connecting Pittsburgh to Cumberland, Maryland - will be presented with a lifetime achievement award during the dinner.

The PA No Till Alliance seeks funding to develop a strategic plan to help develop and implement a clear roadmap for success. The plan will outline tasks, deadlines, budget needs and responsibility charges.
